In the [[modern philosophy|modern]] era, ethical theories were generally divided between [[consequentialist]] theories of philosophers such as [[Jeremy Bentham]] and [[John Stuart Mill]], and [[deontological ethics]] as epitomized by the work of [[Immanuel Kant]].
  +   +
Perhaps the most original ethicist of the modern era - and potentially the most forward-looking - was 17th century philosopher [[Baruch Spinoza]] whose most famous work ''Ethics'' is based on the principle of ethics (defined as the philosophical opposition between right and wrong, as mental states) as opposed to moralism (defined as the theological opposition of good versus evil) where Spinoza, as the book title suggests, comes out in favor of the ethical rather than moralist approach to moral philosophy. Spinoza's ethical principles were revived in the 20th century by a number of leading European thinkers, from [[Jacques Derrida]] to [[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Jürgen Habermas]]. Deleuze even wrote two books on Spinozist ethics, both carrying the title ''Spinoza''.
